citation.article-title: Succinate decarboxylation by Propionigenium maris sp. nov., a new anaerobic bacterium from an estuarine sediment

p.s: Description of Propionigenium maris sp. nov.
Propionigenium maris (ma'ris, L. n. mare the sea; L. gen. n. maris of the sea; referring to the tidal mud flats from which the organism was isolated)
The cells are normally oval to round-ended short rods, 1.0 μm wide by 1.2-2.5 μm long, but under some culture conditions the cells can be up to 50 μm long.
Spores are not formed, and the cells are not motile.
The wall structure is of a gram-negative type, and the cells stain gram negative.
P. maris has a chemoorganotrophic, fermentative metabolism.
In the presence of yeast extract, a number of carbohydrates and amino and organic acids are fermented and increase the growth yield.
These substrates include succinate, fumarate, pyruvate, citrate, 3-hydroxybutyrate, glucose, fructose, maltose, aspartate, lysine, threonine, glutamate, and cysteine.
Typical organic end products of catabolism include formate, acetate, propionate, and butyrate.
Carbohydrates are fermented to formate, acetate, ethanol, and lactate.
Hydrogen is produced from carbohydrates and yeast extract, ammonia from amino acids, and sulfide from cysteine.
Sulfate, sulfur, thiosulfate, and nitrate are not reduced.
Catalase activity is not present.
Indole is formed from L-tryptophan.
Esculin and urea are not hydrolyzed.
Growth requires anoxic conditions.
The temperature optimum for growth is 34–37°C, and no growth occurs at 43°C.
The optimum pH for growth is between pH 6.9 and 7.7, and the limits are pH 5.3 and 8.8.
Growth is possible at 5 and at 55 g/l NaCl, but not at 2 or 60 g/l.
Optimal growth is obtained at 15-20 g/l NaCl.
No cytochromes are formed.
The DNA base ratio is 40 mol% G+C (determined by thermal denaturation).
Phylogenetic analysis reveals a close relationship between P. maris and P. modestum.
Both species form a distinct lineage within a phylogenetically coherent group characterized by Leptotrichia buccalis, Sebaldella termitidis and Fusobacterium spp.
The type strain of P. maris, strain 10succ1 (DSM 9537), was isolated from an anoxic intertidal sediment and is deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Braunschweig, Germany.
